text: Boats in the harbor. Sunlight glinting off the water. Old clapboard houses set in what appears to be a genuine fish village. All with a view of Manhattan.
City Island is a fishing village, located in the Bronx, New York, a place most people associate with machete’s, chop-shops, the Son of Sam, gang warfare and the once great New York Yankees.

head_text.subj: SHOTS OF FAMILIES LEAVING THEIR HOUSES FOR WORK

The locals opening their shops in the morning, bidding each other a good day.

Now: City Island is distinct from the rest of the Bronx by virtue of being located on it’s own two lane spit, right in the middle of the Sound. Most people don’t believe it until they see it. And within the one square mile that comprises all there is of City Island lies another distinction. That of the muscle-sucker versus the clam digger.

We got this little house in the back. Really a boatshed. You can stay there. (musing) In fact, I’m thinking we can do a little deal with each other—you know, I do you a favor, you do me a favor. Tony’s eyes: not good!
Vince Jr. smokes a cigarette. Sees the Rambler. Stubs it out and runs into the house—

Up the stairs and into the bathroom where he speed-brushe his teeth. He reaches inside a closet for a towel. Vince's acting book falls from its hiding place. Vince Jr. stares at it. Opens it and sees the mugshot of Tony. Vince Jr. looks puzzled.
Vince pulls up to his house and parks. Stops and looks at his son. TONY (uncomfortably) What? VINCE (pause, then) Nothin’. Vince smiles goofily. He’s with his long lost son!  30
Can I ask you..like..why I’m chained to a Dodge?
I’1l unchain you in minute. Soon as you calm down. First I wanna tell you something. (breathes, then) See Tony, this is my home. My home which my grandparents built and which I share with my family.
You got them chained up in the house too? VINCE (ignores this) You're gonna get real food and a nice place to live for the first time in three years.
And all of this is because you knew my bitch mother?
Well Nan was difficult, but she was also-
A drunk and a whore?
No! Why would you say that?

She used to punish me for not boosting cases of Vodka from the liquor store where I worked by screwing my friends. Which base does “drunk and whore” not cover? VINCE (gingerly) Don’t you have any nice memories of her? TONY (sullenly) At least she was around. My father left before I was born.  3 Pause. Then--
That all you know about him?
He’s dead. Vince's eyes say: so that’s what she told him.
That’s too bad.
Only thing that’s too bad is I didn’t get to visit his deathbed and dance on his ugly face for leaving me with that bitch. Vince’s face: taking in their father/son vibe.
Vince gets out. Unchains Tony but then rechains him to hi own wrist.
Do I ever get uncuffed?
In a minute. I don’t want you running away or anything before you see what a nice set-up I’m offerin’ you.

Run away. Gee. Why would I do that? They walk, chain in chain, down the side of the house... VINCE JR. Watches from an upstairs window. What he sees is: his fat chained to a young, tough-looking guy walking him to the back of their house. He stares at the two of the them.
A little one-car shed in the back of the house. Vince hau the door open.
32 A concrete floor, a cot and exposed plumbing. Tony takes this in.
I started building it a couple of summers ago but got busy with other things. So this is where our little deal comes in. (pause) You're gonna help me build a bathroom.
Scuse me?

My wife’s been wanting me to add a bathroom and I saw on your sheet that your last job was as a handyman. So that’s the deal. Thirty days back here, build me a bathroom, I'll pay you a fair wage and then you get to go wherever the hell you want with a few bucks in your pocket. Sees that Vince is for real.
How’m I supposed to build a bathroom with handcuffs on me?

Sorry. (as he unlocks them) Just don’t go running away. If you do I‘1l find you and personally toss your ass back in the cage. And they won’t be kiddin’—you’1ll be back in for a long stretch. Okay, Tony? TONY (pause, then) Whatever.
Say ‘Okay, Vince, I promise you that.’ TONY (by rote) ‘Okay, Vince, I promise you that.’

‘And thank you for getting my ass outta the cage.’ Come on.  Vince smiles. This handcuffs. Then he lights one. The sound of A CAR Vince tokes, stubs smoke away. 33 TONY (reluctantly) Thanks for getting my ass outta the cage.
And no more talkin’ shit about your mother. Maybe she wasn’t perfect but she was..she was...
A good lay? makes Tony smile too. Vince unlocks the pulls out a pack of cigarettes and APPROACHING. Panic in Vince’s eyes.
Shit. My wife.
Is that what you call her? ‘Shit, my wife?’ the butt out on the floor and waves the
I don’t smoke.
I can tell.
And don’t tell her where we met. Just say we’re old friends.
We on a bowling team together?
And my daughter’s home from college so..you know..take it easy. TONY (honestly puzzled) Take it easy?
And don't mention that I knew your mom. Tony eyes: what a piece of work.  34
Joyce and Vivian enter, arms full of “Bloomie’s” packages

Anybody home? Vince Jr. appears at the top of the stairs. VINCE JR. I’m here. So’s dad. He’s in the garage with some dude. They’re handcuffed to each other and have been back there for quite some time. Joyce’s face: turning colors.

Tony sits in the garage, the door open. He’s listening to MAJOR ARGUMENT being played out a few feet away. None of is going as planned. VINCE AND JOYCE are in the kitchen but the backdoor is op We see them coming and going as the raging argument continues.
You bring some filthy biker into my home without even so much as asking me—
He happens to be a nice young man and he’s working for his board.
Where'd you meet this guy anyway?
He was getting’ outta jail in a month, so I told them I’d take responsibility!
He’s a criminal? What, Vince, you just picked a con at random to bring into my house?
I knew his mother! And since when is it your house? My grandparents built this house!  35
What do you mean you knew his mother? When? Who was she?

Tony sits, listening glumly. The matches hit the floor. He stares at them. On the cover: HELL’S HALF ACRE. A caricature of a curvaceous woman in red. He stares at it curiously. VINCE (0.s.) Jesus, you think I never met another woman on the face the earth aside a you? She was just a.. an old friend! As the argument goes on, Tony looks up and sees Vince Jr. in the window. JOYCE (o.s.) The answer is no, Vince! NO, NO, NO. I’m not cooking for an extra person. He can’t stay here. And if you don’t like it- Vince Jr. stares gravely at Tony. Then he gives him a thu up. Smiles at him. Tony gives him a thumbs up and smiles back.
They eat in uncomfortable silence. Tony gobbles up the home-cooked food. VINCE JR. Guess this is better than the crap they serve you in jail, huh? Vince hits Vince Jr. on the arm.
Hey! VINCE JR. (recoils in fake pain) Ow, my peptic ulcer!
Shut-up Vin. VINCE JR. (mimics her) “Shut up Vin”. “You shut up Vivian”. “No way!" “Way!”  36
Shhhh! (pause, then) Vince says he was friends with your mom. TONY (mouth full) Oh yeah. Long time ago, I guess.
I guess so. I never heard about it.
It was before we met, sweetie.

Vince says she’s a nice woman. (and then, pointedly) Good looking I bet. Tony shrugs. Nervous eye contact between Joyce, Vivian, Vince and Vince Jr. Vivian whacks Vince Tony’s eyes go wide. VINCE (a statement) What.
What what? VINCE JR. Mom, dad's right. Why don’t you just come right out and ask him if he had sex with her?
Jesus! Jr. in the head. VINCE JR. (recoils in fake pain) Aggh-my brain tumor! What the hell kind of family is this?
Vinnie, you apologize to me!
Actually, sweetie, he has a point. I mean, that’s what you were getting at, right? You were circling the airport a little but—  37
I don’t care if you had sex with her or not. Why’re you two ganging up on me? Vince Jr., pleased with himself for having jumpstarted the argument, watches it like a Tennis match.
Honey, please, after twenty years I know where you’re headed before even you do.
Well that must be real boring for you, Vince. Really. Who knew I was failing to keep you entertained all these years?
Oh Mom, he didn’t mean it like—
Now you're on his side too, huh?
Why does it have to be about “sides”? I’m just saying that dad says things in a stupid way and--
I’m stupid, huh? Listen, maybe you talk to your college friends like that--
Good, Vince, blame her for getting a real education—
Stop!!! Everyone looks at their plates, privately wounded.
watches the family as they recede into their own thoughts He continues shoveling food down. Long pause. Then— VINCE JR. I’m sorry, Vivian.
Thank you.  38 VINCE JR. Can I ask you a question?

What? VINCE JR. (pause, then) Are your breasts continuing to grow? Because, to my eye, they’re much larger now than they used to be. CHAOS. Everyone screaming at once. Tony can’t believe wha he’s seeing. VINCE (boiling over) How dare you speak to her like that!
Upstairs! Go to your room! VINCE JR. “Go to your room?” Pretty lame, mom!

Don’t you sass your mother! Go to your room right now! Vince Jr. looks thrilled. He bolts up the stairs singing— VINCE JR. Internet-ay! Libertay, egalitay, internet-ay! Pause. Temporary calm. Tony continues to eat, not making eye contact but CHECKING OUT EVERYONE SURREPTITIOUSLY. Hi eyes travel to Vivian’s chest. Then to Vince. Vince is also looking at his daughter’s chest. What?
Vince!

Hey! Where you goin’?

I didn’t do nothing! (gets up, throws napkin down) Oh, the hell with it. Hell with everyone! Vince storms upstairs. Now it’s just Tony and Joyce. She looks away, trying to keep herself from emotionally exploding. A beat.
Uh..dinner was great. Joyce nods, looks away. She’s crying.
Vince cruising the Cross-Bronx Expressway. He dials his cell.
Molly Charlesworth is in serious dish mode. She’s with a handsome man, drinking Manhattans.

Then my brother had an affair with my stepfather who met my mother in re-hab—-this was pre-Liz & Fortensky and I was sent away to boarding school in Switzerland and— (her cell rings-she answers) Hello? (pause, she smiles) Well hello Vincent.
I’m callin’ you on a whim. I was thinking maybe we could work on our secrets thing. You know? Tell you the truth... (pause, then) I’m a little stuck. With what to do with my son and everything...

MOLLY (into phone) My brother? Overdosed on heroin in the mens room of the diner on forty- second and tenth? Hold his hand and tell him I’m on my way! I’1l be there in ten minutes, Vincent! (to her date) I’m sorry, you understand, we’ll re-sked when I’m avail. And she's off, leaving a bewildered date in her wake.
VINCE (confused) Scuse me? But the phone is dead. Vince’s face: a slow smile as he realizes that she just dumped a guy to meet him.
The strip-club where Vivian works. She storms in, pulling hair out of its bun. BRUNO the bartender smiles at her. The place is packed with a drunken, boorish Saturday night crowd.
Spring break over?
Do me a favor? Ask Autumn if she wants to go home early tonight and aplit her shift with me.

Highly unlikely. Asian invasion is out in force. He nods with his head. Vivian looks. A table of a dozen Asian businessmen are tipping Autumn with hundred dollar bills. Joyce exits from the kitchen and sits on a lounge chair. She has a pack of cigarettes and a glass of wine in her hand. She sits and looks up as she sees— TONY is sitting across the yard in the fold out chair. He sees her. Nods a greeting.

Nods back. Lights a cigarette. JOYCE (across yard) My husband thinks I quit. Tony’s face: a private smile at his realization that Vinc and Joyce are equally guilty. TONY (yells across yard) One good thing about the joint—they don’t let you smoke anymore. I quit.

Bein’ in prison and not bein’ able to smoke? That must be like..bein’ in jail. An odd pause as Tony considers this. 57. INT. VINCE JR.’s ROOM Vince Jr. is on-line. The site is: REAL CENTERFOLDS! Lots of pictures of blonde, bronzed, California models. His ey not interested. And worried too. Then— Vince Jr. types in “DENISEBBW.COM” and waits. A moment later, there’s the fat neighbor! He stares, both fascinat and ashamed. DENISE (on internet) Hi! I’m Denise and I’m a proud BBW. That's “big beautiful woman” for those of you new to this. I’m Five-eight, three-hundred and fifty pounds and I think eating and being a big beautiful woman is the sexiest thing in the world! If you join my club, you'll get twenty-  42 four hour access to a live image of my kitchen, where I spend most of my time when I’m not working. As she continues, Vince Jr. grabs a credit card belonging VINCENT RIZZO that he keeps displayed quite openly on his desk and enters the numbers. Hits JOIN NOW. He waits. Energized! Digging it! 58. INT. DINER WEST 42"? Street. NIGHT Vince and Molly, drinking coffee, eating French fries. A copy of BACKSTAGE is on the table.
He’s a good guy, you can tell. Must have had a hell of a time with Nan. Wasn't like I was any help. (pause, then) Only thing is he still don’t know..who I am.

You must tell him, Vincent. Think of the drama of the moment. On the other hand, think of the drama of not telling him. Wait! Don’t think of anything, for Godssake! (she closes her eyes—and then) No. You must tell him. The longer he doesn’t know your true identity, the greater the sense of betrayal. He’s been betrayed enough. VINCE (guiltily) All started with me walkin’ out on him.

No, don’t succumb to self-flagellation. I mean I understand it—it’s wonderfully Catholic, but you’re beyond it. You've opened up your home to a convicted felon. You’ve even shown him great trust by leaving him alone with your family. VINCE (dawning) Jesus.  43

Because he’s your blood and if you can’t trust your blood, what the hell can you trust? Now you must take the final step and reveal his birthright to him. She inhales, satisfied that the decision is correct. Smil at Vince. A beat. He smiles back at her. One of those sha smiles that could go just about anywhere. Vince lowers his eyes first. They fall on her copy of ‘BACKSTAGE’, sitting on the table between them.
What’s that?

Ugh. It’s an addiction. “Backstage”-- the Wall Street Journal for struggling actors. You peruse it for news on open calls for parts you won’t get in projects that are never made. For instance: (as she opens it and reads) Open call: Male, age 30-50, working- class type, no agency rep. required. Monday, 9 am, Canal Street Armory. (pause, thoughtfully) Hm. That one might be good for you.
What happens—how’s it work?

You've never auditioned? Oh Vincent, it’s dreadful. You go and wait in a room crowded with people who look vaguely familiar. They march you in. They stare at you. They hate you. You sing and dance and show off all of the talent that once thrilled your mother and father. They make faces. Sometimes they ask a question—very rarely. You're dismissed. You leave feeling like a failure.
Sounds...scary.  44
Having said that..you really should go on this one. It sounds perfect for you. She tears out the ad. Gives it to Vince who reads it. Intrigued.
Tony and Joyce drinking wine, staring at the water and th view of the city.
You must think we’re a bunch of—
No, no, not at all.
I mean, we don’t always act like a bunch of-—
No, forget it I..I understand. Long pause. Then, with radical simplicity—

Families are tough. Joyce looks at Tony. Appreciates his calm stoicism. 60. INT. VINCE JR.’S ROOM Vince Jr. is staring at the site. A spinning umbrella. Then he hears-- DENISE (on internet) Welcome, my new fat-friendly fan! Vince Jr. looks at his computer, excited. DENISE (on internet) You're now an official member of my club. If you see me at a BBW function in the New York area where I live, you can tell me you're a special member by saying our secret word: BOTERO. VINCE JR. (to himself) Botero. A moment later, an image of a kitchen appears.  45
Denise moves around the kitchen, juggling baking pans, cookie sheets etc. Vince Jr. gets up. Backs away from the computer, keeping his eyes on the screen, as if it might vanish. He leaves the room—
--and descends the stairs. Looks. Nobody around. He leave
Vince Jr. exits, hops off the porch and approaches Denise house. The windows are set rather high up. Vince Jr. gets on a concrete block and peers into—

There she is, just like on the computer, juggling baking pans, cookie sheets. Vince Jr. stares in fascination. 63. ExT. 59° STREET TRAMWAY NIGHT The Tram that takes you, high above Manhattan, across to Roosevelt Island. As the tram rises into the air.. «we see that it is indeed a starry, starry night.
Molly and Vince are the only two on the tram. Vince looks out, a little mystified at where he is and how he got here. As she stares out at the stars—
The answers are all there. Don’t worry, Vincent. For some reason, you’re very close to God right now. I don’t know why..but you can feel it in the stars. (dawning) Of course! Mercury’s in retrograde.
Mercury's a what?  46

Mercury—the wing-footed messenger. Represents communication and the process of life. Retrograde: traveling backwards. It happens three or four times a year— and since all backward movement symbol- izes a return to source, our atten- tions turn towards unfinished business. It can be a fine time for completing things. Re-connecting. Settling accounts. (and then) Letting the stars do their plentiful work. Vince looking at her. Something about her way...

Is it kinda strange that what you say makes sense to me? MOLLY (shakes head no—then) Yes. But everything’s strange, Vincent. When you think of it, acting is one of the strangest things a person could choose to do with themselves. Pretending to be another person—who was dreamed up by a third party! It’s like agreeing to be a marionette. Vince turns this around in his mind.
Why you an actress then?
Oh really. What else could I do? What other profession would accommodate my behavioral problems? VINCE (smiles) Yeah. Sort of like getting paid for being a screw-up.
Perfect. They both look off at the view.

Joyce and Tony.  47 JOYCE (resigned) I feel like I spend my whole life trying to please everyone, and all it does is make ‘em mad. My son--Jesus what a pill he’s becomin’! And Vivian. Twenty years of working for that law firm so I could put away enough for her to go to law school after she graduates. You'd think she’d at least talk to me about it. I ask her about her classes and she just shrugs. “Whatever...” And Vince and his ‘poker game’. Does he think I buy that crap? TONY (a little shrug) I grew up with a mother and no father. And my mother hated my father so much for leaving that she took it out on me cause I reminded her of him. Joyce lights another cigarette. Stares off into the yard and blows smoke.

He started that room three years ago. Bought enough wood and junk to build a forest. That was gonna be his new career—-building stuff. He was all gung-ho and then..pffffttt. (shrugs ) He gets discouraged when things take too long. Like more than an hour. Tony clutches himself against the cool air. Joyce sees th
Upstairs in my son’s room? There’s a bunch of sweaters. First door on the left. He nods and gets up...

Tony bounds up the stairs and enters 67. VINCE JR.’s ROOM Nobody's home. The lights are out. Only the glow of the computer is on. Tony stares at the screen.  48 DENISE (on internet) Welcome, my new fat-friendly fan! You're now an official member of my club. If you see me at a BBW function in the New York area where I live, you can tell me you're a special member by saying our secret word: BOTERO. Tony scowls at the computer. TONY (to himself) Botero. 68. EXT. DENISE’S KITCHEN WINDOW Vince Jr. watches Denise. VINCE JR. (under) Botero... Then--the concrete block he’s on sways backwards.
Vince Jr. falls backwards into a fence. Big noise.
Looks up, frightened.
Hey! Hello! Who’s out there? Vince Jr. scrambles to his feet, hops over a hedge and ru into his house.
Molly and Vince sitting on a bench looking at the gloriou Manhattan view.
So. You been thinkin’ anymore about your “worst secret?”
I think about it all the time.
You probably got so many interesting secrets—  He lets it hang. 49
Scads—
--it’s hard to tell which one’s the best. (pause, then) I gonna get to hear it? I don’t mean to press you or nothin’, but we got class comin’ up in a few days and...
Where do you live, Vincent?
The Bronx.
No thonx.
Huh?
Nothing. Ogden Nash. Skip it. For all I know, the Bronx is lovely.
Well, my part of it is. S’called City Island. Old fishing village.

Really? (this appeals to her) City..Island. On the one hand a paradox— a peaceful island located within the world’s busiest city. Further, the words stand in stark relief from each other—"city”, so short and abrupt and definite and “island”—exotic, unknowable and with the silent “s”.
I never really thought about it that way. It’s a great spot, though—my grandparents built the house and passed it down. Once you live there you can’t really think of moving anywhere else.

Every busy city needs an island of peace. Like every busy soul needs a  50 place of repose. A place where we hide from our own frantic stories while they..madly, insanely, obsessively pursue us. Pause. This last was said with a vigor that denotes to Vi another side of Molly, another angle. He looks at her, unafraid and unbashful. Molly looks him right in the eyes Then, she opens her purse and pulls out an envelope. She hands it to Vince.
There it is, Vincent. My secret. He begins to open the envelope. But she stops him.

No. Not yet. I need it to stay mine for just a little longer. Once you know it, it’s no longer truly a secret. (mysteriously) There’1l be a moment when it’s obvious. Carry it with you. The moment could come at anytime. Molly and Vince smile at each other. A beat. As they look out at the glittering view of Manhattan—
Oh, Vincent. What a wonderful time to have not disappeared. MONTAGE — SUNDAY AT THE RIZZO’S
A plume of smoke emanates from the upstairs window. We hear Vince coughing. 71. VINCE JR.’s ROOM He’s asleep with his head on his desk, his computer still on Denise’s website.
Vivian comes crashing in, obviously hungover. She opens the fridge, grabs a bottle of Coke, and chugs it. Goes outside.
Vivian passes the garage, pausing as she sees—  51
Already awake, doing push-ups on the cement floor of the garage room. He doesn’t notice her. She glares at him, mistrust in her eyes. She walks away. Tony keeps doing pushups.

text: hidden from view. Vivian lights a cigarette and stands there, smoking and swigging her Coke. A small window into the garage is open, behind her. A caricature of a curvaceous woman in red. He stares at it curiously, as he continues his exercises.

Then I figure we run the pipe through her and tap into the main line. (a little labored) Feels good building something. Don’t it? Tony nods but looks off. He sees—
making coffee in the kitchen. She meets his eyes. Tony smiles at her. They each look away, bashfully.
Vince and Tony carrying bags of cement from the rear of the garage to the front. Tony has his shirt off. A large tattoo of a cobra is on his back.
You know, my grandfather built this house. Way back. Before I was born. (pause, then) Came here from the old country and became a fish scaler.  52
Oh yeah?
Yeah. Him and his brother. Couple of real mussel suckers. TONY (puzzled) How’s that?

Well, here on City Island, if you come from somewhere else you’re known as a ‘muscle-sucker.’ But if you’re born and raised here you’re a ‘clam-digger.’ Old City Island custom. Tony stares at Vince like: who is this guy?
Huh. As Tony grabs another bag, we see the expression on Vince face: he and Tony are not connecting.
Vince lights up, blowing the smoke through the tiny windo He notices Tony staring at the poster of “The Godfather.”
If I could come back as some-body different, it’d be him. TONY (warily) Don Corleone?

No. Brando. (and then) Always kinda thought being an actor is something I could do. Fact, I’m takin’ this acting class in the city. I guess it’s kind of stupid-I ain’t even told my wife. She thinks I gotta poker game. Tony’s eyes: remembering Joyce’s accusation of the night before.
And all you really got goin’ is an acting class?  53
Shh. Don’t tell no-one. He offers a cigarette to Tony, who refuses it. Pause. Vince’s eyes: Vince is interested
I quit inside.
Yeah, they got that rule now. Must suck.
Plenty other things that are worse. guilty at what he knows must go on.
We try to keep an eye on things. It’s hard—so many guys, so many groups and gangs. But we see somethin’ goin’ on that we don’t like, believe you me-- TONY (a little icy) I took care of myself.
Oh yeah? TONY (shrugs) I figured as soon as I got to Southcourt I had to act more psycho than everyone else. I mean, I was younger so I had to watch myself. in this. He peers at Tony.
What’d you do?
I went right up to the ugliest guy I could find and said: “I think I’m pissed off with you but I don’t know why. Do I got a reason?” VINCE (smiles) No shit?

Yeah. I was like: gimme your top ten reasons you’re a piece of shit and I’1l let you know when somethin’ rings a  54 bell. Just don’t lie to me and don’t figure me for one of your sissy-boys who're gonna put out for you, you sadly deformed excuse for humanity posing as a piece of prison garbage. (pause, he shrugs) It worked. They thought I was psycho. I was just..acting. Tony turns away. Keeps working. But Vince looks at Tony. Admiration in his eyes. And yearning to connect to him. 79. j.INT. RIZZO HOUSE Tony wanders over to the living room where he sees
She looks up from her book.
Think it’s lunchtime. VIVIAN (an odd grunt) Nhhff. She buries her head in her book. Tony stares at her for a beat. Then he leaves.
Brunch time. Vince, Vince Jr. Vivian and Tony sit as Joyce serves up bacon, pancakes etc.
What time you get in, Vince?
I dunno. Midnight.
Win any money? Playing poker? She makes “quote” signs as she says poker. Vince drops hi fork and stares at her.
Okay. That was extremely provocative, mom!  55 VINCE (makes quote signs) What does this mean, huh? As the argument continues--

Taking a walk. VINCE JR. I’d join you, dad, but I’m waiting for a crack delivery from a group of black friends I've developed a close relationship to in school. Some might call it... Joyce looks out the window. Sees Vince walking away. She grabs her cigarettes from a drawer, steps outside and lights one. Tony is hauling away a pile of old lumber. Hot out. His shirt’s off.
